publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for Humphrey Robinson ... and for Humphrey Moseley ...,

note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: _SIr, you'r the very friend I wiſh'd to meet with,
I have a large diſcourſe invites your eare
To be an Auditor.

sp.speaker: Gaſ.
sp.l: And what concernes it?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: The ſadly thriving progreſſe of the loves
Betweene my Lord the Prince, and that great Lady,
Whoſe in●olencie, and never-yet-match'd pride,
Can by no Character be well expreſt,
But in her onlie name, the prow'd Erota.

sp.speaker: Gaſ.
sp.l: Alas Melitus, I ſhould gheſſe, the beſt
Succeſſe your Prince could find from her, to be
As harſh as the event doth prove: but now
'Tis not a time to pity paſſionate griefes,
When a whole Kingdome in a manner lies
Upon its death-bed bleeding.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Who can tell
Whether or no, theſe many plagues at once
Hang over this unhappie Land, for her ſake,
That is a monſter in it.

sp.speaker: Gaſ.
sp.l: Here's the miſerie
Of having a child our Prince: elſe I preſume
The bold Venecians had not dar'd to attempt
So bloudie an Invaſion.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Yet I wonder
Why, Maſter Secretarie, ſtill the Senate
So almoſt ſuperſtitiouſlie adores,
Gonzalo the Venetian Lord, conſidering
The outrage of his Countrymen—

sp.speaker: Gaſ.
sp.l: The Senate
Is wiſe, and therein juſt, for this Gonzalo,
Upon a Maſſacre performed at Sea
By the Admirall of Venice, on a Merchant
Of Candy, when the cauſe was to be heard
Before the Senate there, in open Court
Profeſſed, that the crueltie the Admirall
Had ſhewed, deſerved not only fine, but death:
For Candy then, and Venice were at peace:
Since when upon a motion in the Senate,
For conqueſt of our Land, 'tis known for certaine,
That only this Gonzalo dar'd to oppoſe it,
His reaſon was, becauſe it too much ſavoured
Of Lawleſſe, and unjuſt ambition.
The wars were ſcarce begun, but he (in feare
Of quarrels 'gainſt his life) fled from his Countrie,
And hether came, where (to confirme his truth)
I know (Melitus) he, out of his owne ſtore,
Hath monied Caſſilanes the Generall.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: What, without other pledges then Caſſilanes
Bare promiſe of payment?

sp.speaker: Gaſ.
sp.l: No, it may be
He has ſome pettie Lordſhip to retire to:
But this he hath done; now 'tis fit Melitus,
The Senate ſhould be thankefull, otherwiſe,
They ſhould annihilate one of thoſe Laws,
For which this Kingdome is throughout the world
Unfollowed, and admired.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: What Lawes are theſe? ſir,
Let me ſo much importune you.

sp.speaker: Gaſ.
sp.l: You ſhall,
And they be worth your knowledge; briefly thus:
Who ere he be that can detect apparantly
Another of ingratitude, for any
Received benefit, the Plaintiffe may
Require the offenders life; unleſſe he pleaſe
Freely, and willingly to grant remiſſion.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: By which ſtrict Law the Senate is in danger,
Should they neglect Gonzalo.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Right; the Law
Permits a like equalitie to Aliens,
As to a home-borne Patriot.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Pray ſir the other?

sp.speaker: Gaſ.
sp.l: Know Melitus,
The elder Cretans flouriſhed many yeares,
In War, in Peace, unparalel'd, and they
(To ſpurre heroicke ſpirits on to vertue)
Enacted that what man ſo ere he were,
Did nobleſt in the field againſt his enemie,
So by the generall voice approv'd, and knowne,
Might at his home-returne, make his demand
For ſatisfaction, and reward.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: They are
Both famous Lawes indeed. Enter a Meſſenger.

sp.speaker: Meſ.
sp.l: Maſter Secretarie,
The Senate is about to ſit, and crave
Your preſence.

sp.speaker: Gaſ.
sp.l: What, ſo ſuddenly?

sp.speaker: Meſ.
sp.l: Theſe Letters
Will ſhew the cauſes why.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: Heaven thou art great,
And worthie to be thanked▪

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Your countenance ſir
Doth promiſe ſome good tidings.

sp.speaker: Gaſ.
sp.l: O the beſt
And happieſt for this land, that e're was told!
All the Venetian Forces are defeated.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: How Sir?

sp.speaker: Gaſ.
sp.l: And what doth adde ſome delight more,
There is amongſt the Souldiers a contention
Who ſhall be the triumpher and it ſtands
Doubtfull betweene a Father and his Son,
Old Caſſilanes, and young Antinous.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Why may not both demand it?

sp.speaker: Gaſ.
sp.l: The Law denies it:
But where the Souldiers do not all conſent,
The parties in contention, are refer'd
To plead before the Senate; and from them,
Upon an open Audience, to be judg'd
The Chiefe, and then to make demands.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: You raviſh me
With wonder and delight,

sp.speaker: Gaſ.
sp.l: Come: as we walke,
I ſhall more fully informe you. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaen. 2.
div.stage: Enter Caſſilanes, Arcanes, Antinous, and Decius.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Admit no Souldier neare us, till the Senate
Have tooke their places.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: You are obey'd, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Decius, fall off.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: I ſhall.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Give leave Arcanes:
Young-man come nearer to me: who am I?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: It were a ſin againſt the piety
Of filiall duty, If I ſhould forget
The debt I owe my father on my knee;
Your pleaſure?

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: What, ſo low? canſt thou finde joynts,
Yet be an Elephant? Antinous, riſe:
Thou wilt belye opinion, and rebate
The ambition of thy gallantry, that they
Whoſe confidence thou haſt bewitched, ſhould ſee
Their little God of War, kneele to his father,
Though in my hand I did graſpe Thunder.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sir,
For proofe that I acknowledge you the Author
Of giving me my birth, I have diſcharg'd
A part of my obedience. But if now
You ſhould (as cruell fathers do) proclame
Your right, and Tyrant like uſurp the glory
Of my peculiar honours, not deriv'd
From ſucceſſary, but purchas'd with my bloud,
Then I muſt ſtand firſt Champion for my ſelfe,
Againſt all interpoſers.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Boldly urg'd,
And proudly, I could love thee, did not anger
Conſult with juſt diſdaine, in open language
To call thee moſt ungratefull. Say freely,
Wilt thou reſigne the flatteries, whereon
The reeling pillars of a popular breath,
Have rais'd thy Giant-like conceit; to adde
A ſuffrage to thy fathers merit, ſpeake?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sir, heare me: were there not a Chronicle
Well pend by all their tongues, who can report
What they have ſeene you do; or had you not
Beſt in your owne performance writ yourſelfe,
And been your own Text, I would undertake
Alone, without the helpe of Art, or Character,
But only to recount you deeds in Armes,
And you ſhould ever then be fam'd a preſident
Of living victory: But as you are
Great, and well worthy to be ſtiled great,
It would betray a povertie of ſpirit
In me to obſtruct my fortunes, or diſcent,
If I ſhould coward-like ſurrender up
The intereſt, which the inheritance of your vertue,
And mine owne thriftie fate can claime in honour:
My Lord, of all the maſſe of fame, which any
That weares a ſword, and hath but ſeen me fight,
Gives me, I will not ſhare, nor yeild one jot,
One tittle.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Not to me?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You are my father,
Yet not to you.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Ambitious boy, how darſt thou
To tell me, that thou wilt contend?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Had I
Been ſloathfull, and not followed you in all
The ſtreights of death, you might have juſtly then
Reputed me a baſtard; 'tis a cruelty,
More then to murther Innocents, to take
The life of my yet Infant-honour from me.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Antinous, looke upon this badge of age,
Thy fathers gray-hair'd beard: full fifty yeares,
(And more then halfe of this, ere thou wert borne)
I have been knowne a Souldier, in which time
I found no difference 'twixt War and Peace,
For War was peace to me, and Peace was war;
Antinous, marke me well; there hath not liv'd
Theſe fifty yeares, a man whom Creet prefer'd
Before thy farher; let me boldly boaſt,
Thy father, both for Diſcipline, and Action,
Hath ſo long been the firſt of all his Nation;
Now canſt thou thinke it honeſt, charitable,
Nay humane, being ſo young, my ſon, my child,
Begot, bred, taught by me, by me thy father,
For one dayes ſervice, and that on thy firſt,
To rob me of a glory which I fought for
A halfe of hundred yeares.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: My caſe obſerves
Both equity, and preſidents; for ſir,
That very day whereon you got your fame,
You tooke it from ſome other, who was then
Chiefe in repute, as you are now; and had been
Perhaps as many yeares deſerving that,
Which you gain'd in a day, as I have mine.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: But he was not my father then Antinous.
Thou leav'ſt out that.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sir had he been your father,
He had been then immortall: for a father
Heightens his reputation, where his ſon
Inherits it, as when you give us life,
Your life is not diminiſh'd, but renew'd
In us, when you are dead, and we are ſtill
Your living Images.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: So be thou curs'd
In thy poſterity, as I in thee,
Diſhonorable boy: O ſhall that Sun,
Which not a yeare yet ſince, beheld me mounted
Upon a fierie ſteed, waving my ſword,
And teaching this young-man to manage Armes,
That was a raw, freſh novice in the feates
Of Chivalrie, ſhall that ſame ſun be witneſſe
Againſt this brat, of his ingratitude?
Who to ecclipſe the light of my renowne,
Can no way hope to get a Noble name,
But by the treading on his fathers greatneſſe;
Thou wilt not yeald? Enter Arcanes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: My life, but not the prize
My Sword hath purchas'd.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: The Senate
My Lord are here at hand; and all the ſouldiers
Begin to throng about them.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Now Arcanes the—

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: What ſir?

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Trifles will affront us: that
Fine fighting Stripling,

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Let him have the ſhame on't:
Pleaſe you withdraw on this ſide.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: My great heart
Was never quaild before.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: My Lord be confident,
Let not your father dant you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Decius, whether
Muſt I withdraw?

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: On this ſide.—See the Souldiers
Attend your pleaſure—courage ſir; the Senate.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Way for the Senate.
sp.stage: Enter Porphicio, Poſſenme (3 Senators) Gonzalo, Gaſpero, Souldiers..
sp.l: My good Lords I know not
What taxe of arrogance I may incurre,
Should I preſume, though courted by your favours,
To take a place amongſt you: I had rather
Give proofe of my unfeign'd humility
By force, though meane, yet more becomming place,
Then run the hazard of a doubtfull cenſure.

sp.speaker: Poſ.
sp.l: My Lord, your wiſedome is both known & try'd;
We cannot ranke ye in a nobler friendſhip,
Then your great ſervice to the ſtate deſerves.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: Wil't pleaſe you ſit? Enter Fernando with Sold.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: What here my Lord Porphicio?
It muſt not be.

sp.speaker: Porp.
sp.l: My Lord you are too modeſt.

sp.speaker: Gonz
sp.l: It is no ſeaſon to be troubleſome,
Elſe—But I have done: Your Lordſhips are obſerv'd.

sp.speaker: Goſp.
sp.l: Is the demandant ready?

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: He is ready.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.l: Produce him then.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Before this ſacred preſence,
I, by a generall conſent, am made
The Souldiers voice, and to your gratious wiſedomes,
Preſent as chiefe in Armes, his Countries Champion,

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Moſt reverend Lords, you heare the leſſer number
Of thoſe who have been Guardians to this Countrey,
Approve this Champion; I in all their names
Who fought for Candy, here preſent before you
The mightieſt man in Armes, Antinous.
Speak fellow ſouldiers.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.l: Stand by all, ſave the two competitors.

sp.speaker: Poſſ.
sp.l: My Lords, how much your Countrey owes you both,
The due reward of your deſertfull glories
Muſt to poſterity remain: But yet
Since, by our Law, one onely can make claime
To the propoſed honours which you both
(It ſeems) have truely merited, take leave
Freely to plead your rights: we ſhall attend you.

sp.speaker: Porp.
sp.l: Wherein priority of voyce is granted
Lord Caſſilanes to you: for that your rare
And long experience in the courſe of war,
As well doth challenge it, as the beſt priviledge
Of Order and civility, for that
You are your brave opponents worthy father.
Say Countrey-men, are you content?

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: I, I.

sp.speaker: Caſſ.
sp.l: Right grave, right gratious fathers; how unfit
It is for me, that all my life time have
Been practis'd in the ſchoole of bloud, and ſlaughter,
To bandy words now in my lifes laſt farewell,
Your wiſedomes will conſider; were there pitcht
Another, and another field, like that
Which not yet three days ſince, this arme hath ſcatter'd,
Defeated, and made nothing, then the man
That had a heart to thinke he could but follow,
(For equall me he ſhould not) through the lanes
Of danger and amazement, might in that,
That onely of but folowing me, be happy,
Reputed worthy to be made my rivall:
For 'tis not Lords, unknowne to thoſe about me,
(My fellow ſouldiers) firſt with what a confidence
I led them on to fight, went on ſtill, and
And as if I could have beene a ſecond Nature,
As well in heartning them by my example,
As by my exhortation, I gave life
To quicken courage, to inflame revenge,
To heighten reſolution; in a word,
To out-doe action: It boots not to diſcover,
How that yong-man, who was not ſledg'd nor skil'd
In Martiall play, was even as ignorant
As childiſh: But I liſt not to diſparage
His non ability: The ſignall given
Of Battaile, when our enemies came on,
(Directed more by fuerie, then warrant
Of Policy and Stratagem) I met them,
I in the fore-front of the Armies met them;
And as if this old weather-beaten body
Had been compos'd of Cannon-proof, I ſtood
The volleys of their ſhot. I, I my ſelfe
Was he that firſt diſ-rankt their woods of Pikes:
But when we came to handy-ſtroaks, as often
As I lent blowes, ſo often I gave wounds,
And every wound a death. I may be bold
To juſtifie a truth, this very ſword
Of mine ſlew more then any twaine beſides:
And, which is not the leaſt of all my glorie,
When he, this young man, hand to hand in fight,
Was by the Generall of the Venetians,
And ſuch as were his retinue, unhors'd,
I ſtept between, and reſcu'd him my ſelfe,
Or horſes hoofs had trampled him to dirt;
And whilſt he was re-mounting, I maintain'd
The combate with the gallant Generall,
Till having taken breath, he throng'd hefore me,
Renew'd the fight, and with a fatall blow,
Stole both that honour from me, and his life
From him, whom I before my ſelfe alone,
Had more then full three quarters kill'd: A man
Well worthy onely by this hand to have dy'd,
Not by a Boyes weak puſh: I talke too much,
But 'tis a fault of Age: If to bring home
Long peace, long victorie, even to your Capitoll;
If to ſecure your Kingdome, Wives, and Children,
Your lives and liberties; if to renowne
Your honours through the world, to fix your names,
Like Blazing ſtarres, admir'd, and fear'd by all,
That have but heard of Candy, or a Cretane,
Be to deſerve the approvement of my man-hood,
Then thus much have I done: what more, examine
The Annalls of my life; and then conſider
What I have been, and am. Lords I have ſaid.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: With reverence to the Senate, is it lawfull,
Without your Cuſtomes breach, to ſay a word?

sp.speaker: Poſ.
sp.l: Say on my Lord Gonzalo.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: I have heard,
And with no little wonder, ſuch high deeds
Of Chivalrie diſcours'd, that I confeſſe,
I doe not think the Worthies while they liv'd
All nine, deſerv'd as much applauſe, or memorie,
As this one: But who can doe ought to gaine
The Crowne of honour from him, muſt be ſomewhat
More then a man; you tread a dangerous path,
Yet I ſhall heare you gladly: for believe me,
Thus much let me profeſſe, in honours cauſe,
I would not to my father, nor my King,
(My Countries father) yield: if you tranſcend
What we have heard, I can but onely ſay,
That miracles are yet in uſe. I feare
I have offended.

sp.speaker: Porp.
sp.l: You have ſpoken nobly.
Antinous uſe your priviledge.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Princely fathers.
E're I begin, one ſuit I have to make,
'Tis juſt, and honourable.

sp.speaker: Porp.
sp.l: Poſſ. Speak, and have it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: That you would pleaſe the ſouldiers might all ſtand
Together by their Generall.

sp.speaker: Poſſ.
sp.l: 'Tis granted.
All fall to yonder ſide: Goe on, Antinous.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I ſhall be briefe and plaine: All what my father
(This Countries Patron) hath diſcours'd, is true.
Fellowes in Armes: ſpeak you is't true?

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: True, true.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: It followes, that the blaze of my performance
Took light from what I ſaw him doe; and thus
A City (though the flame be much more dreadfull)
May from a little ſparke be ſet on fire;
Of all what I have done, I ſhall give inſtance
Onely in three maine proofs of my deſert.
Firſt I ſought out (but through how many dangers
My Lords judge ye) the chiefe, the great Commander,
The head of that huge body, whoſe prowd weight
Our Land ſhrunke under, him I found and fought with,
Fought with, and ſlew. Fellowes in Armes, ſpeak you,
Is't true or not?

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: True, true.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: When he was falne,
The hearts of all our adverſaries
Began to quaile, till young Fernando, ſonne
To the laſt Duke of Venice gather'd head,
And ſoone renew'd the field, by whoſe example
The bold Venetians doubling ſtrength and courage
Had got the better of the day, our men
Suppoſing that their adverſaries grew
Like Hydra's head, recoyle, and 'gan to ſlye:
I follow'd them; and what I ſaid, they know;
The ſumme on't is; I call'd them back, new rankt them;
Lead on, they follow'd, ſhrunk not till the end:
Fellowes in Armes is't true, or no.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: True, true.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Laſtly, to finiſh all, there was but one,
The onely great exploit; which was to take
Fernando priſoner, and that hand to hand
In ſingle fight I did: my ſelfe without
The helpe of any arme, ſave the arme of heaven.
Speak ſouldiers, is it true, or no?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Behold my priſoner, Fathers.

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.l: This one man
Ruin'd our Army, and hath glorifi'd
Creete in her robes of mightineſſe and conqueſt.

sp.speaker: Poſ.
sp.l: We need not uſe long circumſtance of words,
Antinous thou art conquerer: the Senate,
The ſouldiers, and thy valour have pronounc'd it.

sp.speaker: Porp.
sp.l: Make thy demand.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Pleaſe ye (my Lord) give leave
That I may part.

sp.speaker: Poſ.
sp.l: No Caſſilanes, the Court
Should therein be diſhonour'd, doe not imagine
We prize your preſence at ſo ſlight a rate.
Demand Antinous.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thus (my Lords) to witneſſe
How far I am from arrogance, or thinking
I am more valiant, though more favour'd
Then my moſt matchleſſe father, my demand is,
That for a laſting memorie of his name,
His deeds, his reall, nay his royall worth,
You ſet up in your Capitoll in Braſſe
My fathers Statue, there to ſtand for ever
A Monument and Trophy of his victories,
With this Inſcription to ſucceeding ages,
Great Caſſilanes, Patron of Candy's Peace,

sp.speaker: Por. Poſ.
sp.l: It is granted. What more?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No more.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: How boy?

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Thou art immortall,
Both for thy Son-like pietie, and beauties
Of an unconquer'd minde.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: My Priſoner (Lords)
To your more ſacred wiſedomes I ſurrender:
Fit you his ranſome; halfe whereof I give
For largeſſe to the Souldiers: the other halfe
To the erection of this monument.

sp.speaker: Caſſ.
sp.l: Ambitious villaine.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Thou art all un-immitable.
My Lords to work a certaine peace for Candy
With Venice, uſe Fernando like a Prince;
His ranſome Ile disburſe what e're it be:
Yet you may ſtay him with you, till conditions
Of amitie ſhall be concluded on:
Are yee content?

sp.speaker: Porp.
sp.l: We are, and ever reſt
Both friends add debters to your nobleneſſe.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Souldiers attend me in the Market-place,
Ile thither ſend your largeſſe.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: I have a ſute too, Lords.

sp.speaker: Porp. Poſ.
sp.l: Propoſe it, 'tis yours, if fit and juſt.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Let not my ſervices,
My being forty yeares a drudge, a pack-horſe
To you, and to the State, be branded now
With Ignominy ne're to be forgotten:
Reare me no Monument, unleſſe you meane
To have me fam'd a Coward, and be ſtamp'd ſo.

sp.speaker: Poſ.
sp.l: We underſtand you not.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Proud boy, thou doſt,
And Tyrant-like inſult'ſt upon my ſhame.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sir, heaven can tell, and my integrity,
What I did, was but onely to inforce
The Senates gratitude. I now acknowledge it.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Obſerve it Fathers, how this haughty boy
Growes cunning in his envy of mine honours:
He knowes no mention can of me be made,
But that it ever likewiſe muſt be told,
How I by him was maſter'd; and for ſurety
That all ſucceeding times may ſo report it,
He would have my diſhonour, and his Triumphs
Ingrav'd in Braſſe: hence, hence proceeds the falſhood
Of his inſinuating piety.
Thou art no childe of mine: thee and thy bloud,
Here in the Capitoll, before the Senate,
I utterly renounce: So thrift and fate
Confirme me; henceforth never ſee my face,
Be, as thou art, a villaine to thy father.
Lords I muſt crave your leaves: come, come Arcanes. Ex.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Here's a ſtrange high-borne ſpirit.

sp.speaker: Poſ.
sp.l: Tis but heat
Of ſuddaine preſent rage; I dare aſſure
Antinous of his favour.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I not doubt it,
He is both a good man, and a good father.
I ſhall attend your Lordſhips.

sp.speaker: Poſſ.
sp.l: Doe Antinous.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Yes: feaſt thy Triumphs,
With applauſe and pleaſures.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: Poſſ. Lead on. Exeunt. Flor. Cornets.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I utterly renounce—'Twas ſo?
Was't not, my Decius?

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Piſh, you know my Lord,
Old men are chollerick.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: And laſtly parted
With, never henceforth ſee my face: O me,
How have I loſt a Father? Such a father?
Such a one Decius! I am miſerable,
Beyond expreſſion.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Fie, how unbecomming
This ſhewes upon your day of fame?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O miſchiefe:
I muſt no more come neare him; that I know,
And am aſſur'd on't.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Say you doe not?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: True:
Put caſe I doe not: what is Candy then
To loſt Antinous? Malta, I reſolve
To end my dayes in thee.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: How's that?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Ile trie
All humble meanes of being reconcil'd,
Which if deny'd, then I may juſtly ſay,
This day has prov'd my worſt: Decius my worſt. Exeunt

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.l: NOw to what you have heard; as no man can
Better then I, give you her Character;
For I have been both nurs'd, and traind up to
Her petulant humours, and been glad to beare them,
Her brother, my late Maſter, did no leſſe:
Strong apprehenſions of her beauty hath
Made her believe that ſhe is more then woman:
And as there did not want thoſe flatterers
'Bout the worlds Conquerour, to make him think,
And did perſwade him that he was a god;
So there be thoſe baſe flies, that will not ſtick
To buzze into her eares ſhe is an Angel,
And that the food ſhe feeds on is Ambroſia.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: She ſhould not touch it then, 'tis Poets fare.

sp.speaker: Gaſ.
sp.l: I may take leave to ſay, ſhe may as well
Determine of her ſelfe to be a goddeſſe,
With leſſer flatterie then he a god:
For ſhe does conquer more, although not farther.
Every one looks on her dyes in deſpaire,
And would be glad to doe it actually,
To have the next age tell how worthily,
And what good cauſe he had to periſh ſo:
Her beauty is ſuperlative, ſhe knowes it,
And knowing it, thinks no man can deſerve,
But ought to periſh, and to dye for her:
Many great Princes for her love have languiſh'd,
And given themſelves a willing ſacrifice,
Proud to have ended ſo: And now there is
A Prince ſo manded in his owne paſſions,
That he forgets the Royaltie he was borne to,
And deems it happineſſe to be her ſlave.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: You talke as if you meant to winde me in,
And make me of the number.

sp.speaker: Gaſ.
sp.l: Sir, miſtake me not, the ſervice that I owe ye
Shall plead for me: I tell you what ſhe is,
What ſhe expects, and what ſhe will effect,
Unleſſe you be the miracle of men,
That come with a purpoſe to behold,
And goe away your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: I thanke you, I will doe it: But pray reſolve me,
How is the ſtor'd with wit?

sp.speaker: Gaſ.
sp.l: As with beauty,
Infinite, and more to be admired at,
Then medled with.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: And walks her tongue the ſame gate with her feet?

sp.speaker: Gaſ.
sp.l: Much beyond: what ere her heart thinks, ſhe utters:
And ſo bold, ſo readily, as you would judge
It penn'd and ſtudied.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.p: She comes. Enter Erota, Philander, Annophill, Hyparcha, Mochingo, Attendants.

sp.speaker: Gaſ.
sp.l: I muſt leave you then,
But my beſt wiſhes ſhall remain with you.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Still I muſt thanke you.
This is the moſt paſſionate,
Moſt pitifull Prince,
Who in the Caldron of affections,
Looks as he had been par-boyl'd.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: If I offend with too much loving you,
It is a fault that I muſt ſtill commit,
To make your mercy ſhine the more on me.

sp.speaker: Erot.
sp.l: You are the ſelfe-ſame creature you condemne,
Or elſe you durſt not follow me with hope
That I can pittie you, who am ſo farre
From granting any comfort in this kinde,
That you and all men elſe ſhall periſh firſt:
I will live free and ſingle, till I finde
Something above a man to equall me;
Put all your brave Heroes into one,
Your Kings and Emperours, and let him come
In perſon, of a man, and I ſhould ſcorne him:
Muſt, and will ſcorne him.
The god of Love himſelfe hath loſt his eyes,
His Bow and Torch extinguiſh'd, and the Poets
That made him firſt a god, have loſt their fire
Since I appear'd, and from my eyes muſt ſteale it.
This I dare ſpeak; and let me ſee the man,
Now I have ſpoke it, that doth, dare deny;
Nay, not believe it.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: He is mad that does not.

sp.speaker: Erot.
sp.l: Have not all the nations of the earth heard of me?
Moſt come to ſee me, and ſeeing me, return'd
Full of my praiſes? teaching there Chroniclers
To make their Stories perfect? for where the name,
Meerely the word of faire Erota ſtands,
It is a laſting Hiſtory to time,
Begetting admiration in the men,
And in my owne Sex envie; which glorie's loſt,
When I ſhall ſtick my beautie in a cloud,
And clearely ſhine through it.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: This Woman's in the altitudes, and he muſt be
A good Aſtrologer ſhall know her Zodiack.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: For any man to thinke
Himſelfe an able purchaſer of you,
But in the bargaine there muſt be declar'd
Infinite bounty: otherwiſe I vow,
By all thats excellent and gracious in you,
I would untenant every hope lodg'd in me,
And yield my ſelfe up Loves, or your owne Martyr.

sp.speaker: Erot.
sp.l: So you ſhall pleaſe us.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: O you cannot be
So heavenly, and ſo abſolute in all things,
And yet retaine ſuch cruell tyranny.

sp.speaker: Erot.
sp.l: I can, I doe, I will.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: She is in her
Moods, and her Tences: Ile Gramer with you,
And make a triall how I can decline you:
By your leave (great Lady.)

sp.speaker: Erot.
sp.l: What are you?

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: A man, a good man, that's a wealthy;
A Proper man, and a proud man too; one
That underſtands himſelfe, and knowes, unleſſe
It be your ſelf, no woman on the Univerſe deſerves him.
Nay, Lady, I muſt tell you too withall.
I may make doubt of that, unleſſe you paint
With better judgement next day then on this;
For (plaine I muſt be with you) 'tis a dull Fucus.

sp.speaker: Erot.
sp.l: Knowes any one here what this fellow is?

sp.speaker: Attend.
sp.l: He is of Venice (Madam) a great Magnifico,
And gracious with the Senate.

sp.speaker: Erot.
sp.l: Let him keep then among them; what makes he here?
Heres ſtate enough where I am: here's a doe—
You, tell him, if he have ought with us, let him
Look lower, and give it in Petition.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Mighty Magnifico, my Miſtris bid me tell you,
If you have ought with her, you muſt look lower,
And yeeld it in Petition.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Here is for thee a Ducket.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: You ſay well ſir, take your owne courſe.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: I will not grace you
(Lady) ſo much as take you by the hand;
But when I ſhall vouchſafe to touch your lip,
It ſhall be through your Court a holy-day
Proclamed for ſo high favour.

sp.speaker: Erot.
sp.l: This is ſome
Great mans Jeſter: Sirrah, begone, here is
No place to foole in.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Where are the fooles you talke of?
I doe keep two.

sp.speaker: Erot.
sp.l: No queſtion of it: for
In your ſelfe you doe maintaine an hundred.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: And beſides them I keep a noble traine,
Statiſts, and men of action: my purſe is large and deep,
Beyond the reach of riot to draw drie:
Fortune did vie with Nature, to beſtow
(When I was borne) her bountie equally:
Tis not amiſſe you turne your eyes from me;
For ſhould you ſtand and gaze me in the face,
You periſh would, like Semele by Iolus:
In Venice at this inſtant there do lye
No leſſe then threeſcore Ladies in their graves,
And in their Beds five hundred for my love.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: You lie more then they; yet it becomes him bravely;
Would I could walke and talke ſo? Ile endeavour it.

sp.speaker: Erot.
sp.l: Sir, doe you know me?

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Yes, you were ſiſter to the late Prince of Candy,
Aunt to this young one: And I in Venice,
I am borne a Lord; equall to you in fortunes,
In ſhape; Ile ſay no more, but view.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: There needs no more be ſaid, were I a woman—
O he does rarely: in ſhape; Ile ſay no more,
But view: Who could ſay more, who better?
Man is no man, nor woman woman is,
Unleſſe they have a pride like one of theſe.
How poore the Prince of Cyprus ſhewes to him?
How poore another Lady unto her:
Carriage and State makes us ſeem demi-gods,
Humility, like beaſts, wormes of the earth.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Royall Lady, I kiſſe your hand.

sp.speaker: Erot.
sp.l: Sir, I know you not.

sp.speaker: Anno.
sp.l: O my noble Brother, welcome from the wars.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Deare ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: Where is my father, that you come without him?
We have news of your ſucceſſe: he has his health I hope?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes ſiſter, he has his health, but is not well.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: How not well? what Riddles do you utter?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Ile tell you more in private.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Noble ſir,
I cannot be unmindfull of your merit,
Since I laſt heard it: you are a hopefull youth,
And (indeed) the ſoule of Candy.
I muſt ſpeak my thoughts.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: The Prince of Cyprus Brother, Good Decius.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I am his ſervant.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: You are the Patron of your Countrie, ſir,
So your unimitable deeds proclame you,
It is no language of my owne, but all mens.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Your Enemies muſt needs acknowledge it:
Then doe not thinke it flatterie in your friends,
For if they had a heart, they could not want a tongue.

sp.speaker: Erot.
sp.l: Is this your brother Annophill?

sp.speaker: Anno.
sp.l: Yes Madam.

sp.speaker: Erot.
sp.l: Your name's Antinous?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I am (Lady) that moſt unfortunate man.

sp.speaker: Erot.
sp.l: How unfortunate? are you not the ſouldier,
The Captaine of thoſe Captaines, that did bring
Conqueſt and victory home along with you?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I had ſome ſhare in't; but was the leaſt
Of the leaſt worthy.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: O ſir, in your modeſty youl'd make
A double Conqueſt: I was an eare-witneſſe
When this young man ſpoke leſſer then he acted,
And had the ſouldiers voice to helpe him out:
But that the Law compell'd him for his honour,
To inforce him make a claime for his reward,
I well perceive he would have ſtood the man
That he does now, buried his worth in ſilence.

sp.speaker: Erot.
sp.l: Sir, I hearken not to him, but looke on you,
And finde more in you then he can relate?
You ſhall attend on me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Madam, your pardon.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: Deny it not ſir, for it is more honour
Then you have gotten ith' field: for know you ſhall,
Upon Erota's asking, ſerve Erota.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I may want anſwers, Lady,
But never want a will to doe you ſervice.
I came here to my ſiſter, to take leave,
Having enjoyn'd my ſelfe to baniſhment,
For ſome cauſe that hereafter you may heare,
And wiſh with me I had not the occaſion.

sp.speaker: Anno.
sp.l: There ſhall be no occaſion to divide us:
Deare Madam for my ſake uſe your power,
Even for the ſervice that he ought to owe,
Muſt, and does owe to you, his friends, and countrey.

sp.speaker: Erot.
sp.l: Upon your Loyalty to the ſtate and me,
I doe command you Sir, not depart Candy:
Am I not your Princeſſe?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You are a great Lady.

sp.speaker: Erot.
sp.l: Then ſhew your ſelfe a Servant and a Subject.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I am your vaſſaile.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: You are a Coward; I that dare not fight,
Scorne to be vaſſaile to any Prince in Europe:
Great is my heart with pride, which Ile encreaſe
When they are gone, with practiſe on my Vaſſailes.

sp.speaker: Atten.
sp.l: The noble Caſſilane is come to ſee you Madam,

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: There's comfort in thoſe words, Antinous:
For heres the place, and perſons that have power,
To reconcile you to his love againe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: That were a fortunate meeting.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Greatneſſe ſtill wait you Lady.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: Good Caſsilane, we doe maintain our greatneſſe,
Through your valour.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: My prayers pull dayly bleſſings on thy head,
My un-offending childe, my Annophill.
Good Prince, worthy Gonzalo! ha? art thou here
Before me? in every action art thou ambitious?
My duty (Lady) firſt offered here,
And love to thee (my childe) though he out-ſtrip me;
Thus in the wars he got the ſtart on me,
By being forward, but performing leſſe;
All the endeavours of my life are loſt,
And throwne upon that evill of mine owne
Curſed begetting, whom I ſhame to father.
O that the heat thou robd'ſt me off, had burnt
Within my Entrailes, and begot a feaver,
Or ſome worſe ſickneſſe, for thou art a diſeaſe
Sharper then any phyſick gives a name to.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: Why doe you ſay ſo?

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: O Annophill; there is good cauſe my girle:
He has plaid the thiefe with me, and filch'd away
The richeſt jewell of my life, my honour,
Wearing it publikely with that applauſe,
As if he juſtly did inherit it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Would I had in my Infancy been laid
Within my grave, covered with you bleſſings,
Then growne up to a man, to meet your curſes.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: O that thou hadſt.
Then I had been the father of a childe,
Dearer then thou wert even unto me,
When hope perſwaded me I had begot
Another ſelfe in thee: Out of mine eyes,
As farre as I have throwne thee from my heart,
That I may live and dye forgetting thee.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: How has he deſerv'd this untam'd anger,
That when he might have ask't for his reward
Some honour for himſelfe, or maſſe of pelfe,
He onely did requeſt to have erected
Your Statue in the Capitoll, with Titles
Ingrav'd upon't, The Patron of his Countrey?

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: That, that's the poiſon in the gilded cup,
The Serpent in the flowers, that ſtings my honour,
And leaves me dead in fame: Gods doe a juſtice,
And rip his boſome up, that men may ſee,
Seeing, believe the ſubtle practiſes
Written within his heart: But I am heated,
And doe forget this preſence, and my ſelfe.
Your pardon, Lady.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: You ſhould not aske, 'leſſe you knew how to give.
For my ſake Caſsilane, caſt out of your thoughts
All ill conceptions of your worthy ſon,
That (queſtionleſſe) has ignorantly offended,
Declared in his penitence.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Bid me dye (Lady) for your ſake Ile doe it;
But that you'll ſay is nothing, for a man
That has out-liv'd his honour: But command me
In any thing ſave that, and Caſsilane
Shall ever be your ſervant. Come Annophill,
(My joy in this world) thou ſhalt live with me,
Retired in ſome ſollitarie nook,)
The comfort of my age; my dayes are ſhort,
And ought to be well ſpent: and I deſire
No other witneſſe of them but thy ſelfe,
And good Arcanes.

sp.speaker: Anno.
sp.l: I ſhall obey you ſir.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Noble ſir:
If you taſte any want of worldly meanes
Let not that diſcontent you: know me your friend,
That hath, and can ſupply you.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Sir, I am too much bound to you already,
And 'tis not of my cares the leaſt, to give you
Faire ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: You may imagine I doe ſpeak to that end,
But truſt me, 'tis to make you bolder with me.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Sir, I thanke you, and may make triall of you,
Meane time my ſervice.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: Brother be comforted; ſo long as I continue
Within my fathers love, you cannot long
Stand out an Exile: I muſt goe live with him,
And I will prove ſo good an Orator
In your behalfe, that you againe ſhall gaine him,
Or I will ſtirre in him another anger,
And be loſt with you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Better I were neglected: for he is haſty,
And through the Choller that abounds in him,
(Which for the time divides from him his judgement)
He may caſt you off, and with you his life;
For griefe will ſtrait ſurprize him, and that way
Muſt be his death: the ſword has try'd too often,
And all the deadly Inſtruments of warre
Have aim'd at his great heart, but ne're could touch it:
Yet not a limbe about him wants a ſcarre.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Madam my duty—

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: Will you he gone?

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: I muſt (Lady) but I ſhall be ready,
When you are pleas'd command me, for your ſervice.
Excellent Prince—To all my heartie love,
And a good farewell.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Thanks honeſt Caſsilane.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Come Annophill.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Shall I not wait upon you ſir?

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: From hence you ſhall not ſtirre a foot:
Loving Gonzalo, it muſt be all my ſtudy
To requite you.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: I may be ſo fortunate to deſerve
The name of friend from you, I have enough.

sp.speaker: C●ſ.
sp.l: You are ſo, and you have made your ſelfe ſo.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: I will then preſerve it.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: Antinous you are my ſervant, are you not?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: It hath pleaſed you ſo to grace me.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: Why are you then dejected? you will ſay,
You have loſt a father; but you have found a Miſtris
Doubles that loſſe: be maſter of your ſpirit;
You have a cauſe for it.: which is my favour,

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: And mine.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: Will no man eaſe me of this foole?

sp.speaker: Gonz:
sp.l: Your fellow.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: Antinous wait upon us.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I ſhall Madam.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Nay but Ladie, Ladie.

sp.speaker: Erot.
sp.l: Sir, you are rude: and if you be the Maſter
Of ſuch meanes as you doe talk of, you ſhould
Learne good manners.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: O Lady, you can finde a fault in me,
But not perceive it in your ſelfe; you muſt, ſhall heare me:
I love you for your pride, 'tis the beſt vertue
In you.

sp.speaker: Erot.
sp.l: I could hang this fellow now: by whom
Are you ſupported, that you dare doe this?
Have you not example here in a Prince
Tranſcending you in all things, yet beares himſelfe
As doth become a man had ſeen my beautie?
Back to your Countrey, and your Curtizans,
Where you may be admired for your wealth,
Which being conſum'd, may be a meanes to gaine you
The opinion of ſome wit. Here's nothing
To be got but ſcorne, and loſſe of time.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Which are things I delight in.

sp.speaker: Erot.
sp.l: Antinous follow me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: She is vext to the ſoule.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Let her be vext, 'tis fit ſhe ſhould be ſo:
Give me thy hand Gonzalo, thou art in our favour,
For we doe love to cheriſh lofty ſpirits,
Such as percuſteere the earrh, and bound
With an erected countenance to the clouds.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: 'S-foot, what thing is this?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I doe love fire-works, becauſe they mount:
An Exhalation I profeſſe to adore,
Beyond a fixed ſtarre, 'tis more illuſtrious,
As every thing rais'd out of ſmoak is ſo:
Their vertue is in action: what doe you think of me?

sp.speaker: Gonz
sp.l: Troth ſir,
You are beyond my gheſſe, I know you not.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Doe you know your ſelfe?

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Yes ſir.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Why you and I are one: I am proud, and
Very proud too, that I muſt tell you; I ſaw
It did become you, couſin Gonzalo, prethee
Let it be ſo.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Let it be ſo good couſin.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I am no great ones foole.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: I hope ſo, for alliance ſake.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Yet I do ſerve the Mighty, Monſtrous, and Magnanimous
Invincible Erota.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: O good couſin, now I have you: Ile meet you in your Coat.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Coat? I have my horſe-mans coat I muſt confeſſe
Lin'd through with Velvet, and a Scarlet out-ſide;
If you'll meet me in't, Ile ſend fort;
And couſin you ſhall ſee me with much comfort,
For it is both a new one, and a right one,
It did not come collaterall.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Adieu good couſin; at this preſent I have ſome buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Farewell (excellent couſin.)

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: CAndy, I ſay, is loſt already.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Yes,
If to be conqueror be to be loſt.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: You have it; one dayes conqueſt hath undone them,
And ſold them to their vaſſalage; for what
Have I elſe toyl'd my braines, profuſely emptied
My moneyes, but to make them ſlaves to Venice,
That ſo in caſe the ſword did loſe his edge,
Then Art might ſharpen hers?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Gonzalo how?

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Fernando thus: you ſee how through this Land,
Both of the beſt and baſeſt I am honour'd;
I onely gave the State of Venice notice,
When, where, and how to land, or you had found
A better entertainment: I was he
Encourag'd young Antinous to affront
The devill his father: for the devill I think
Dares not doe more in battaile.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: But why did ye?
I finde no ſuch great policie in that.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Indeed Fernando, thou canſt fight, not plot:
Had they continu'd one, they two alone
Were of ſufficient courage and performance
To beat an Armie.

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.l: Now by all my hopes,
I rather ſhall admire, then envy vertue.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Why then by all your hopes you'll rather have
Your Braines knockt out, then learne how to be wiſe;
You States-man? Well ſir, I did more then this,
When Caſſilane crav'd from the common treaſure
Pay for his Souldiers, I ſtrook home, and lent him
An hundred thouſand Duckets,

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Marry ſir,
The policy was little, the love leſſe,
And honeſty leaſt of all.

sp.speaker: Gonz
sp.l: How ſay ye by that?
Go fight, I ſay goe fight, Ile talke no more with you,
You are inſenſible.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Well, I ſhall obſerve ye,

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Why look you ſir, by this meanes have I got
The greateſt part of Caſſilanes eſtate
Into my hands, which he can ne're redeem,
But muſt of force ſinke: do you conceive me now?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: So:
But why have you importuned the Senate,
For me to ſojourne with them?

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: There's the quinteſſence,
The ſoule, and grand elixer of my wit:
For he (according to his noble nature)
Will not be knowne to want, though he do want,
And will be bankrupted ſo much the ſooner,
And made the ſubject of our ſcorne and laughter.

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.l: Here's a perfect plotted ſtratagem.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Why? could you
Imagine, that I did not hate in heart
My Countreyes enemies? yes, yes, Fernando,
And I will be the man that ſhall undoe them.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Ye are in a ready way.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: I was never out on't.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Peace,
Here comes a wiſe Coxcombe, a tame Coward.
Now worthy Gaſpero, what,
You come (I know) to be my Lord Fernando's
Conducter to old Caſſilane?

sp.speaker: Gaſ.
sp.l: To wait upon him.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: And my Lords the Senators ſent you?

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.l: My noble Lord they did.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: My Lord Fernando,
This gentleman (as humble as you ſee him)
Is even this Kingdomes treaſure; In a word,
'Tis his chiefe glory that he is not wiſer
Then honeſt, nor more honeſt then approv'd
In truth and faith.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: You may be bold
To truſt him with your boſome, he'll not deceive,
If you relie upon him once.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Your name is Gaſpero?

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.l: Your ſervant.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Goe commend me
(Right honeſt Gaſpero) commend me heartily
To noble Caſſilane, tell him my love
Is vow'd to him.

sp.speaker: Gaſ.
sp.l: I ſhall.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: I know you will.
My Lord I cannot long be abſent from you.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Sir, you are now my guide. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Thus my deſignes
Run uncontroul'd; yet Venice though I be
Intelligencer to thee, in my braine
Are other large Projects: for if proud Erota
Bend to my lure, I will be Candy's King,
And Duke of Venice too. Ha? Venice too?
O 'twas prettily ſhov'd in: why not? Erota
May in her love ſeale all ſure: if ſhe ſwallow
The bait, I am Lord of both; if not, yet Candy
Deſpight of all her power ſhall be ruin'd.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Urge me no farther Annophill.

sp.speaker: Anno.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Thy fathers poverty has made thee happie;
For though 'tis true, this ſolitary life
Sutes not with youth and beautie, O my childe,
Yet 'tis the ſweeteſt Guardian to protect
Chaſte names from Court-aſperſions; there a Lady.
Tender and delicate in yeares and graces,
That doats upon the charmes of eaſe and pleaſure,
Is ſhip-wrackt on the ſhore; for 'tis much ſafer
To truſt the Ocean in a leaking ſhip,
Then follow greatneſſe in the wanton rites
Of luxurie and ſloth.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: My wiſhes ſir,
Have never ſoar'd a higher flight, then truely
To finde occaſion wherein I might witneſſe
My duty and obedience.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: 'Tis well ſaid,
Canſt thou forbeare to laugh Arcanes?

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Why ſir?

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: To look upon my beggerie, to look upon
My patience in my beggerie: Tell me,
Does it ſhew handſome? bravely?
Handſome? thou wilt flatter me,
And ſweare that I am miſerable.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Nothing
More glorifies the noble, and the valiant,
Then to deſpiſe contempt: if you continue
But to enjoy your ſelfe, you in your ſelfe
Enjoy all ſtore beſides.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: An excellent change:
I that ſome ſeven Apprentice-ſhips commanded
A hundred Miniſters, that waited on
My nod, and ſometimes twenty thouſand ſouldiers,
Am now retir'd, attended in my age
By one poore maid, followed by one old man.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Sir, you are lower in your owne repute
Then you have reaſon for.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: The Romane Captaines,
I meane the beſt, ſuch as with their blouds
Purchas'd their Countreyes peace, the Empires glorie,
Were glad at laſt to get them to ſome Farmes,
Off-from the clamours of the ingratefull great ones,
And the unſteddy multitude, to live
As I doe now, and 'twas their bleſſing too,
Let it be ours Arcanes.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: I cannot but
Applaud your ſcorne of injuries.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Of injuries?
Arcanes, Annophill, lend both your hands
So, what ſay yee now?

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Why now my Lord—

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: I ſweare
By all my paſt proſperities; thus ſtanding
Between you two, I thinke my ſelfe as great,
As mighty, as if in the Capitoll
I ſtood amidſt the Senators, with all
The Cretane ſubjects proſtrate at my feet.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: Sir, you are here more ſafe.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: And more beloved:
Why look yee ſirs, I can forget the weakneſſe
Of the traduced ſouldiers, the neglect
Of the faire-ſpoken Senate, the impietie
Of him, the villaine, whom (to my diſhonour)
The World miſcalls my ſon.
But by the—

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Sir, remember that you promis'd no occaſion
Should move your patience.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Thou do'ſt chide me friendly,
He ſhall not have the honour to be thought upon
Amongſt us. Enter a Servant.
Now? the newes?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: The Secretarie,
With the Venetian priſoner, deſire
Admittance to your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: How? to me?
What myſterie is this? Arcanes can they
Thinkſt thou, meane any good?

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: My Lord, they dare not
Intend ought elſe but good.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Tis true, they dare not;
Arcanes welcome them: Come hither Annophill,
Stand cloſe to me, wee'll change our affability
Into a forme of State: and they ſhall know
Our heart is ſtill our owne.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: My Lord—

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: I know them both: Fernando, as you are
A man of greatneſſe, I ſhould under-value
The right my ſword hath fought for, to obſerve
Low-fawning complements, but as you are
A Captive and a ſtranger, I can love you,
And muſt be kinde. You are welcome.

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.l: 'Tis the all
Of my ambition.

sp.speaker: Gaſ.
sp.l: And for proof how much
He truely honours your heroick vertues,
The Senate on his importunity,
Commend him to your Lordſhips guard.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: For what?

sp.speaker: Gaſ.
sp.l: During the time of his abode in Candy.
To be your houſhold gueſt.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Wherein my Lord,
You ſhall more make me debtor to your nobleneſſe,
Then if you had return'd me without ranſome.

sp.speaker: Caſſ
sp.l: Are you in earneſt Sir?

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.l: My ſute to the Senate
Shall beſt reſolve you that.

sp.speaker: Caſſ.
sp.l: Come hither Secretarie,
Look that this be no trick now put upon me:
For if it be—Sirrah.—

sp.speaker: Gaſ.
sp.l: As I have troth
(My Lord) it onely is a favour granted
Upon Fernando's motion from himſelfe:
Your Lordſhip muſt conceive, I'de not partake
Ought, but what ſhould concerne your honour; who
Has been the prop, our Countries ſhield, and ſafety,
But the renowned Caſſilane?

sp.speaker: Caſſ.
sp.l: Applauſe?
Is Gaſpero—puffe—nothing—why, young Lord,
Would you ſo much be ſequeſter'd from thoſe
That are the blazing Comets of the time,
To live a ſolitarie life with me?
A man forſaken? all my hoſpitality
Is now contracted to a few; theſe two,
This tempeſt wearied ſouldier, and this Virgin;
We cannot feaſt your eyes with Maſques and Revells,
Or Courtly Anticks: the ſad ſports we riot in,
Are Tales of foughten fields, of Martiall ſcarres,
And things done long agoe, when men of courage
Were held the beſt, not thoſe well-ſpoken youths,
Who onely carry conqueſt in their tongues;
Now ſtories of this nature are unſeaſonable
To entertaine a great Dukes ſon with.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Herein
Shall my Captivity be made my happineſſe,
Since what I loſe in freedome, I regaine
(With int'reſt) by converſing with a Souldier
So muchleſſe for experience, as great Caſſilane.
Pray ſir admit me.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: If you come to mock me,
I ſhall be angrie.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: By the love I beare
To goodneſſe, my intents are honourable.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Then in a word, my Lord, your viſitations
Shall find all due reſpect: But I am now
Growne old, and have forgot to be an hoſt;
Come when you pleaſe you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Sir, I thank you.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: Good ſir be not too urgent; for my father
Will ſoon be mov'd: yet in a noble way
Of courteſie he is as eaſily conquer'd.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Lady, your words are like your beauty, powerfull;
I ſhall not ſtrive more how to doe him ſervice,
Then how to be your ſervant.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Shee's my daughter,
And does command this houſe.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I ſo conceive her.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Doe you heare?

sp.speaker: Gaſ.
sp.l: My honour'd Lord.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Commend me to them.
Tell 'em I thank them.

sp.speaker: G●ſ.
sp.l: Whom my Lord?

sp.speaker: C●●.
sp.l: The Senate:
Why now come you ſo dull? O they are gratious,
And in●●●●●●●● g●atefull Thou art eloquent,
Speak modeſtly in mentioning my ſervices:
And if ought fall out in the By, that muſt
Of meere neceſſity touch any act
Of my deſerving praiſes, bluſh when you talke on't,
'Twill make them bluſh to heare on't.

sp.speaker: Gaſ.
sp.l: Why my Lord—

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Nay, nay, you are too wiſe now; good, obſerve me,
I doe not raile againſt the hopefull Springall,
That builds up monuments in Braſſe; reares Trophies
With Mottoes and Inſcriptions, quaint devices
Of Poetrie and fiction; let's be quiet.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: You muſt not croſſe him.

sp.speaker: Gaſ.
sp.l: Not for Candys wealth.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: You ſhall for ever make me yours.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: 'Twere pitty to double your captivity.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Who's here, Decius? Enter Decius.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Ha! Decius? who nam'd Decius?

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: My duty to your Lordſhip: I am bold,
Preſuming on your noble and knowne goodneſſe
To.—

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Preſent you with this—

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Letter?

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Yes my honour'd Lord.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: From whom?

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Pleaſe you peruſe
The in-ſide, you ſhall finde a name ſubſcrib'd,
In ſuch humility, in ſuch obedience,
That you your ſelfe will judge it tyranny
Not to receive it favourably.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Hey-day.
Good words my Maſters; this is Court-infection,
And none but Cowards ply them: Tell me, Decius,
Without more circumſtance, who is the ſender?

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Your much griev'd ſonne Antinous.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: On my life
A challenge; ſpeak, as thou art worthy ſpeak:
Ile anſwer't.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Honour'd Sir.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: No honour'd Sirs—
Foole your yong Idoll with ſuch pompous Attributes.
Say briefely, what containes it?

sp.speaker: Dec,
sp.l: 'Tis a lowly
Petition for your favour.

sp.speaker: Caſ,
sp.l: Raſh young man,
But that thou art under my owne roofe, and know'ſt
I dare not any way infringe the Lawes
Of hoſpitality, thou ſhould'ſt repent
Thy bold and rude intruſion. But preſume not
Againe to ſhew thy Letter, for thy life;
Decius, not for thy life.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Nay then (my Lord)
I can with-hold no longer: you are too rough,
And wreſtle againſt nature, with a violence
More then becomes a father: wherein would yee
Come nearer to the likeneſſe of God,
Then in your being entreated? Let not thirſt
Of honour, make you quite forget you are
A man, and what makes perfect man-hoods, comforts
A father.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: If a memory remaine
Of my departed mother; if the purity
Of her unblemiſh'd faith deſerve to live
In your remembrance, let me yet by theſe
Awake your love to my uncomforted Brother.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I am a ſtranger: but ſo much I tender
Your ſons deſertfull vertues, that I vow
His Sword nere conquer'd me ſo abſolutely,
As ſhall your curteſie, if you vouchſafe
At 〈◊〉 our inſtances, to new receive him,
Into your wonted favour.

sp.speaker: Gaſ.
sp.l: Sir, you cannot
Require more low ſubmiſſion.

sp.speaker: Anno.
sp.l: Am I not
Growne vile yet in your eyes? then by the name
Of father, let me once more ſue for him,
Who is the only now remaining-branch
With me, of that moſt ancient roote, whoſe body
You are, deare ſir.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: 'Tis well: an hoſt of furies
Could not have baited me, more torturingly,
More rudely, or more moſt unnaturally?
Decius, I ſay, let me no more heare from him;
For this time goe thou hence, and know from me
Thou art beholding to me that I have not
Killed thee already, looke to't next, looke to't.
Arcanes fie, fie Annophil, Exit.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: He's gone.
Chaf'd beyond ſufferance: we muſt follow him.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Lady, this letter is to you.

sp.speaker: Anno.
sp.l: Come with me,
For we muſt ſpeake in private: pleaſe you ſir,
To ſee what entertainement our ſad houſe
Can yeild? Ex.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I ſhall attend you Lady.

sp.speaker: Gaſ.
sp.l: How do ye like
To ſojourne here, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: More then to feaſt
With all the Princes of the earth beſides;
Gonzalo told me that thou wert honeſt.

sp.speaker: Gaſ.
sp.l: Yes ſir.
And you ſhall find it.

sp.speaker: Fer
sp.l: Shall I?

sp.speaker: Gaſ.
sp.l: All my follies
Be elſe recorded to my ſhame.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Enough,
My heart is here for ever lodg'd.

sp.speaker: Gaſ.
sp.l: The Lady.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: The place admits no time to utter all,
But Gaſpero if thou wilt prove my friend,
I'le ſay thou art—

sp.speaker: Gaſ.
sp.l: Your ſervant: I conceive ye,
Wee'll chooſe ſome fitter leiſure.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Never man
Was (in a moment) or more bleſſ'd, or wretched. Excunt.
sp.stage: Enter Hyparcha, (placing two chaires) Antinous, and Erota.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Leave us.

sp.speaker: Hy.
sp.l: I ſhall. Ex.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Antinous ſit downe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Madam:

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I ſay ſit downe: I do command you ſit;
For looke what honour thou didſt gaine by me,
I can●ot loſe by it: happy Antinous,
The graces, and the higher Deities
Smil'd at thy birth, and ſtill continue it:
Th●n thinke that I (who ſcorne leſſer examples)
Muſt doe the like: ſuch as do taſte my power,
And talke of it, with feare and reverence,
Shall do the ſame unto the man I favour.
I tel thee youth, thou haſt a conqueſt won,
Since thou cam'ſt home, greater then that laſt,
Which dignified thy ſame; greater then if
Thou ſhouldſt goe out againe, and conquer farther;
For I am not aſham'd to acknowledge
My ſelfe ſubdued by thee.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Great Lady—

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Sit ſtill, I will not heare thee elſe: now ſpeake,
And ſpeake like my Antinous, like my Souldier,
Whom Cupid, and not Mars, hath ſent to Battle.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I muſt (I ſee) be ſilent.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: So thou maiſt:
There's greater Action in it than in clamour,
A looke, (if it be gratious) will begin the War,
A word conclude it: then prove no Coward,
Since thou haſt ſuch a friendly enemie,
That teaches thee to conquer.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You do amaze me Madam,
I have no skill, no practice in this War,
And whether you be ſerious, or pleaſe
To make your ſport on a dejected man,
I cannot rightly gheſſe: but be it as it will,
It ir a like unhappineſſe to me:
My diſcontents beare thoſe conditions in them, Muſick.
And lay me out ſo wretched, no deſignes
(How ever truly promiſing a good)
Can make me relliſh ought, but a ſweet-bitter,
Voluntarie Exile. Muſick againe

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Why an Exile?
What comfort can there be in thoſe companions Enter Hyparcha.
Which ſad thoughts bring along with?

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Whence comes this well-tun'd ſound?

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: I know not Madam.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Liſten wench:
What ever friendly hands they are that ſend it Song.
Let 'em play on; they are Maſters of their facultie.
Doth it pleaſe you ſir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: According to the time.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Go to 'em wench,
And tell 'em, we ſhall thanke 'em; for they have kept
As good time to our diſpoſition, as to their inſtruments;
Unleſſe Antinous ſhall ſay he loves, Enter Philander.
There never can be ſweeter accents uttered.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Let then the heart, that did imploy thoſe hands,
Receive ſome ſmall ſhare of your thankes with them,
'Tis happineſſe enough that you did like it;
A fortune unto me, that I ſhould ſend it
In ſuch a lucky minute; but to obtaine
So gratious welcome, did exceed my hopes.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: Good Prince, I thanke you for it.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: O Madam, poure not (to faſt) joyes on me,
But ſprinkle 'em ſo gently, I may ſtand 'em▪
It is enough at firſt, you have laid aſide
Thoſe cruell angry lookes out of your eyes,
With which (as with your lovely) you did ſtrike
All your beholders in an Extaſie.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: Philander, you have long profeſs'd to love me,

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Have I but profeſt it Madam?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Nay, but heare me?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: More attentively, then to an Oracle.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: And I will ſpeake more truly, if more can be:
Nor ſhall my language be wrapt up in Riddles,
But plaine as truth it ſelfe: I love this Gentleman,
Whoſe griefes has made him ſo uncapable
Of Love, he will not heare, at leaſt not underſtand it.
I that have lookt with ſcornefull eyes on thee,
And other Princes mighty in their ſtates,
And in their friends as fortunate, have now prai'd,
In a petitionary kind almoſt,
This man, this wel deſerving man, (that I muſt ſay)
To looke upon this beauty, yet you ſee
He caſts his eyes rather upon the ground,
Then he will turne 'em this way; Philander
You looke pale; I'le talke no more.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Pray go forward: I would be your Martyr,
To dye thus, were immortally to live.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: Will you goe to him then, and ſpeake for me?
You have loved longer, but not ferventer,
Know how to ſpeake, for you have done it like
An Orator, even for your ſelfe: then how will you for me
Whom you profeſſe to love above your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: The curſes of diſſemblers follow me
Unto my grave, and if I do not ſo.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: You may (as all men do) ſpeake boldlier, better
In their friends cauſe ſtill, then in your owne;
But ſpeake your utmoſt, yet you cannot ſeigne,
I will ſtand by, and bluſh to witneſſe it.
Tell him ſince I beheld him, I have loſt
The happineſſe of this life, food, and reſt;
A quiet boſome, and the ſtate I went with.
Tell him how he has humbled the proud,
And made the living but a dead Erota.
Tell him withall, that ſhe is better pleas'd
With thinking on him, then enjoying theſe.
Tell him—Philander, Prince; I talke in vaine
To you, you do not marke me.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Indeed, I do.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: But thou doſt looke ſo pale,
As thou wilt ſpoyle the ſtory in relating.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Not, if I can but live to tell it.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: It may be you have not the heart.

sp.speaker: Phi
sp.l: I have a will I am ſure, how e're my heart
May play the coward, but if you pleaſe, I'le trie.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: If a kiſſe will ſtrengthen thee, I give you leave
To challenge it, nay, I will give it you.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: O that a man ſhould taſte ſuch heavenly bliſſe!
And be enjoyn'd to beg it for another.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Alas, it is a miſerie I grieve
To put you to, and I will ſuffer rather
In his tyranny, than thou in mine.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Nay Madam, ſince I cannot have your love,
I will endeavour to deſerve your pitty:
For I had rather have within the grave
Your love, then you ſhould want it upon earth.
But how can I hope, with a feeble tongue
To inſtruct him in the rudiments of love,
When your moſt powerfull beauty cannot worke it?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Do what thou wilt (Philander) the requeſt
Is ſo unreaſonable, that I quit thee of it.
I deſire now no more, but the true patience,
And fortitude of Lovers, with thoſe helpes
Of ſighes and teares, which I think is all the Phiſick—

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: O if he did but heare you, 'twere enough;
And I will wake him from his Appoplexie.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: My Lord?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Nay pray,
No curteſie to me, you are my Lord,
(Indeed you are) for you command her heart,
That commands mine: nor can you want to know it.
For looke you ſhe that told it you in words,
Explaines it now more paſſionately in teares;
Either thou haſt no heart, or a marble one,
If thoſe drops cannot melt it; prethee looke up,
And ſee how ſorrow ſits within her eyes,
And love the griefe ſhe goes with (if not her)
Of which thou art the parent: and never yet
Was there (by nature) that thing made ſo ſtony,
But it would love what ever it begot.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: He that begot me, did beget theſe cares
Which are good iſſues, though happily by him
Eſteemed monſters: nay, the ill-judging world
Is likely enough to give them thoſe Characters.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: What's this to love, and to love, and to the Lady? he's old,
Wrathfull, perverſe, ſelfe-will'd, and full of anger,
Which are his faults; but let them not be thine;
He thruſts you from his love, ſhe puls thee on,
He doubts your vertues, ſhe doth double them:
O either uſe thy owne eyes, or take mine,
And with them, my heart, then thou wilt love her,
Nay, doate upon her, more then on thy duty,
And men will praiſe thee equally for it;
Neglecting her, condemne thee, as a man
Unworthy ſuch a fortune: O Antinous,
'Tis not the friendſhip that I beare to thee,
But her command, that makes me utter this:
And when I have prevail'd, let her but ſay,
Philander, you muſt dye or this is nothing,
It ſhall be done together with a breath,
With the ſame willingneſſe, I live to ſerve her.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: No more Philander.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: All I have done, is little yet to purpoſe,
But ere I leave him, I will perceive him bluſh;
And make him feele the paſſions that I do,
And every true lover will aſſiſt me in't,
And lend me their ſad ſighs to blow it home,
For Cupid wants a dart to wound this boſome.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: No more, no more Philander, I can endure no more,
Pray let him goe; go good Antinous, make peace
With your owne mind, no matter though I periſh. Ex.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: I Cannot help it.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Nor do I require it,
The malady needs no Phiſitian,
Helpe hoſpitall people.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: I am glad to heare
You are ſo valliant.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Valiant?
Can any man be proud that is not valiant;
Fooliſh woman, what wouldſt thou ſay? thou—
I know not what to call thee.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: I can you,
For I can call you Coxcome, Aſſe, and Puppy.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: You do do it, I thanke you.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: That you'l loſe a fortune,
Which a Cobler better deſerves, then thou doſt.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Do not provoke my magnanimity,
For when I am inſens'd, I am inſenſible;
Go tell thy Lady, that hath ſent me word
She will diſcard me, that I diſcard her,
And throw a ſcorne upon her, which I would not,
But that ſhe does me wrong.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Do you not glory in your conqueſt more,
To take ſome great man priſoner, then to kill him?
And ſhall a Lady find leſſe mercie from you,
That yeilds her ſelfe your Captive, and for her Ranſome,
Will give the jewell of her life, her heart,
Which ſhe hath lockt from all men but thy ſelfe:
For ſhame (Antinous) throw this dulneſſe off,
Art thou a man no where but in the field?

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: He muſt here Drums, and Trumpets ere he ſleeps,
And at this inſtant dreames he's in his Armour:
Theſe Iron-hearted Souldiers are ſo cold,
Till they be beaten to a womans armes,
And then they love 'em better then their owne;
No Fort can hold them out.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What pitty is it (Madam) that your ſelfe,
Who are all excellence, ſhould become ſo wretched,
To thinke on ſuch a wretch as griefe hath made me?
Seldom deſpairing men looke up to heaven,
Although it ſtill ſpeake to 'em in its glories;
For when ſad thoughts perplexe the mind of man,
There is a plumit in the heart, that waighs,
And puls us (living) to the duſt we came from;
Did you but ſee the miſeries you purſue,
(As I the happineſſe that I avoid
That doubles my afflictions) you would flye
Unto ſome wilderneſſe, or to your grave,
And there find better comforts then in me,
For love, and cares can never dwell together.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: They ſhould,
If thou hadſt but my love, and I thy cares.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What wild beaſt in the Deſart, but would be
Taught by this Tongue to leave his crueltie,
Though all the beauties of the face were vail'd!
But I am ſavager than any beaſt,
And ſhall be ſo till Decius do arive,
Whom with ſo much ſubmiſſion I have ſent
Under my hand, that if he do not bring
His Benediction backe, he muſt to me
Be much more crueller, then I to you.

sp.speaker: Ero,
sp.l: Is't but your fathers pardon you deſire?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: With his love, & then nothing next that, like yours.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Decius is come. Enter Decius.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O welcome friend; If I apprehend not
Too much of joy, there's comfort in thy lookes.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: There is indeed: I prethee Decius ſpeake it.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: How? prethee Decius? this woman's ſtrangly alter'd.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Why doſt not ſpeake (good friend) and tell me how
The reverent bleſſing of my life, received
My humble lines; wept he for joy?

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: No, ther's a letter will informe you more:
Yet I can tell you, what I think will grieve you,
The old man is in want, and angry ſtill,
And povertie is the bellowes to the Coale,
More then diſtaſt from you as I imagine.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What's here? how's this? It cannot be: now ſure
My griefes delude my ſenſes.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: In his lookes,
I read a world of changes: Decius marke
With what a ſad amazement he ſurveies
The newes: canſt thou gheſſe what 'tis?

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: None good I feare.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I feare ſo too: and then—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: It is her hand.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Are you not well?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Too well: if I were ought
But Rock, this Letter would conclude my miſeries,
Peruſe it (Lady) and reſolve me then,
In what a caſe I ſtand.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Sir, the worſt is,
Your fathers lowneſſe, and diſtaſte.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No Decius,
My ſiſter writes, Fernando has made ſuite
For love to her: and to expreſſe ſincerely
His conſtant truth, hath like a noble Gentleman,
Diſcovered plots of treachery; contriv'd
By falſe Gonzalo, not intending more
The utter ruine of our houſe, then generally
Candies confuſion.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: 'Tis a generous part
Of young Fernando.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis, and I could wiſh
All thrift to his affections Decius.
You find the ſumme on't Madam.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Yes, I do.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: And can you now yet think a heart oppreſt
With ſuch a throng of cares, can entertaine
An amorous thought? love frees all toyles but one,
Calamitie and it can ill agree.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Wil't pleaſe ye ſpeake my doome?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Alas great Lady,
Why will you ſlatter thus a deſperate man,
That is quite caſt away? O had you not
Procured the Senates warrant to enforce
My ſtay, I had not heard of theſe ſad newes.
What would you have me do?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Love me, or kill me,
One word ſhall ſentence either: for as truth
Is juſt, if you refuſe me, I am reſolute
Not to out-live my thraldome.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Gentle Lady.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Say, muſt I live, or dye?

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: My Lord, how can you
Be ſo inexorable: here's occaſion
Of ſuccouring your father in his wants,
Securely profer'd: pray ſir, entertaine it.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: What is my ſentence?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What you pleaſe to have it?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: As thou art Gentle, ſpeake thoſe words againe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Madam, you have prevail'd; yet give me leave
Without offence, ere I reſigne the intereſt
Your heart hath in my heart, to prove your ſecreſie.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Antinous, 'tis the greateſt Argument
Of thy affections to me.

sp.speaker: Ants
sp.l: Madam, thus then,
My father ſtands for certaine ſummes engag'd
To treacherous Gonzalo; and has more 'gag'd
The greateſt part of his eſtate to him:
If you receive this morgage, and procure
Acquitance from Gonzalo to my father,
I am what you would have me be.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: You'l love me then?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Provided (Madam) that my father know not
I am an Agent for him.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: If I faile
In this, I am unworthy to be lov'd.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Then (with your favour) thus I ſeale my truth,
To day, and Decius witneſſe how unchangingly
I ſhall ſtill love Erota.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Thou haſt quickned
A dying heart Antinous.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: This is well:
Much happineſſe to both. Enter Hyparcha

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: The Lord Gonzalo
Attends you Madam.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Comes as we could wiſh,
Withdraw Antinous, here's a Cloſſet, where
You may partake his errand; let him enter. Enter

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Madam you muſt be wary. Ex. Gonzalo

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Feare it not,
I will be ready for him; to entertaine him
With ſmiling welcome: Noble ſir, you take
Advantage of the time; it had been fit
Some notice of your preſence, might have faſhion'd
A more prepared ſtate.

sp.speaker: Gon●.
sp.l: Do ye mocke me Madam?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Truſt me, you wrong your judgement, to repute
My gratitude a fault: I have examin'd
Your portly carriage, and will now confeſſe
It hath not ſlightly won me.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: The wind's turn'd;
I thought 'twould come to this: it pleas'd us Madam,
At our laſt interview, to mention love,
Have you conſider'd on't?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: With more then common
Content: but ſir, if what you ſpake, you meant,
(As I have cauſe to doubt) then—

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: What, (ſweet Lady?)

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Methinks me ſhould lay by this forme of ſtatelineſſe.
Loves courtſhip is familiar, and for inſtance,
See what a change it hath begot in me,
I could talke humbly now, as Lovers uſe.

sp.speaker: Gon●.
sp.l: And I: and I: we meet in one ſelfe-center,
Of bleſt conſent.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I hope my weakeneſſe ſir,
Shall not deſerve neglect: but if it prove ſo,
I am not the firſt Lady has been ruin'd
By being too credulous: you will ſmart for't one day.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Angell-like-Lady, let me be held it villaine,
If I love not ſincerely.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Would I knew it?

sp.speaker: Gon▪
sp.l: Make proofe by any fit command.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: What, do ye meane to many me?

sp.speaker: Gon●
sp.l: How? meane? nay more, I meane
To make you Empreſſe of my earthly fortunes,
Regent of my deſires, for did ye covet
To be a reall Queene, I could advance you.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Now I perceive you ſlight me, and would make me
More ſimple then my ſexes frailety warrants.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: But ſay your mind, and you ſhall be a Queene.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: On thoſe conditions, call me yours.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Enough,
But are we ſafe?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Aſſuredly.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: In ſhort,
Yet Lady firſt be plaine: would you not chooſe
Much rather to prefer your own Sun-riſing,
Then any's elſe though ne're ſo neere entituled
By bloud, or right of birth?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Tis a queſtion
Needs not a reſolution.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Good: what if
I ſet the Crowne of Candy on your head?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I were a Queene indeed then.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Madam, know
There's but a boy 'twixt you, and it ſuppoſe him
Tranſhap'd into an Angell.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Wiſe Gonzalo,
I cannot but admire thee.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: 'Tis worth thinking on:
Beſides your husband ſhall be Duke of Venice.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Gonzalo, Duke of Venice?

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Ye are mine ye ſay.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Piſh: you but dally with me; and would lull me
In a rich golden dreame.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: You are too much diſtruſtfull of my truth.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Then you muſt give me leave to apprehend
The meanes, and manner how.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Why thus—

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: You ſhall not,
We may be over-heard; Affaires and counſels
Of ſuch high nature, are not to be truſted
Not to the Aire it ſelfe, you ſhall in writing,
Draw out the full deſigne; which if effected,
I am as I profeſſe.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: O I applaud
Your ready care, and ſecreſie.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: There is a bar yet, twixt our hopes and us,
And that muſt be remov'd.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: What is't?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Old Caſſilane.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: He? feare not him: I build upon his ruines
Already.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I would find a ſmoother courſe
To ſhift him off.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: As how?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Wee'l talke in private,
I have a ready plot.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: I ſhall adore you. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Madam, although I hate unnoble practices,
And therefore have perform'd no more then what
I ought, for honours ſafety: yet Annophil,
Thy love hath been the ſpur, to urge me forward
For ſpeedier diligence.

sp.speaker: Anno.
sp.l: Sir your owne fame
And memory will beſt reward themſelves.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: All gaine is loſſe (ſweet beauty) if I miſſe
My comforts here: The brother and the ſiſter
Have double conquer'd me, but thou maiſt triumph.

sp.speaker: Anno.
sp.l: Good ſir, I have a father.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Yes, a brave one;
Could'ſt thou obſcure thy Beauty, yet the happineſſe
Of being but his daughter, were a dowre
Fit for a Prince: what ſay ye?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: You have deſerv'd
As much as I ſhould grant.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: By this faire hand
I take poſſeſſion.

sp.speaker: Anno.
sp.l: What in words I dare not,
Imagine in my ſilence.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Thou art all vertue.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: I'le tell thee how: Baldwin the Emperour,
Pretending title, more through tyranny,
Then right of conqueſt, or deſcent, uſurp'd
The ſtile of Lord o're all the Grecian Iſlands,
And under colour of an amity
With Cre●t, preferd the Marqueſſe Mountferato
To be our Governor; the Cretians vex'd
By the ambitious Turkes, in hope of aide
From the Emperour, received for Generall,
This Mountferato; he (the wars appeaſed)
Plots with the ſtate of Venice, and takes money
Of them for Candy: they paid well, he ſteales
Away in ſecret; ſince which time, that right
The ſtate of Venice claimes o're Candy, is
By purchaſe, not inheritance, or Conqueſt:
And hence growes all our quarrell.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: So a uſurer
Or Lumbard-Jew, might with ſome bags of traſh,
Buy halfe the Weſterne world.

sp.speaker: Caſ
sp.l: Money Arcanes
Is now a God on earth: it cracks virginities,
And turnes a Chriſtian, Turke;
Bribes juſtice, cut-throats honour, does what not?

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Not captives Candy.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Nor makes thee diſhoneſt,
Nor me a Coward—Now ſir, here is homely,
But friendly entertainment.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Sir, I find it.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: And like it, do ye not?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: My repaire ſpeakes for me.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Fernando we were ſpeaking off—how this?
sp.stage: Enter Gonzalo, and Gaſpero, with a Casket.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Your friend, and ſervant.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Creditors, my Lord,
Are Maſters and no Servants: as the world goes,
Debters are very ſlaves to thoſe to whom
