They have been beholding to; in which reſpect,
I ſhould feare you Gonzalo.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Me my Lord?
You owe me nothing.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: What nor love, nor money?

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Yes, love, I hope not money.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: All this braverie,
Will ſcarcely make that good.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: 'Tis done already:
See ſir, your Morgage which I only took,
In caſe you and your ſon had in the wars
Miſcarried: I yeild it up againe: 'tis yours.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Are ye ſo conſcionable?

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: 'Tis your owne.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Piſh, piſh, I'le not receive what is not mine,
That were a dangerous buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Sir, I am paid for't,
The ſummes you borrowed, are return'd; The bonds
Cancell'd, and your acquittance formerly ſeal'd:
Looke here ſir, Gaſpero is witneſſe to it.

sp.speaker: Gaſ.
sp.l: My honoured Lord, I am.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: My Lord Fernando,
Arcanes and the reſt, you all ſhall teſtifie,
That I acquit Lord Caſſilane for ever,
Of any debts to me.

sp.speaker: Gaſ.
sp.l: 'Tis plaine and ample:
Fortune will once againe ſmile on us fairely.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: But hearke ye, hearke ye, if you be in earneſt,
Whence comes this bounty? or whoſe is't?

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: In ſhort,
The great Erota, by this Secretary,
Returned me my full due.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Erota? why
Should ſhe do this?

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: You muſt aske her the cauſe,
She knowes it beſt.

sp.speaker: Caſ
sp.l: So ho; Arcanes, none
But women pitty us? ſoft-hearted women,
I am become a brave fellow now, Arcanes,
Am I not?

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Why ſir, if the gracious Princeſſe
Have tooke more ſpeciall notice of your ſervices,
And meanes to be more thankfull than ſome others,
It were an injury to gratitude,
To diſeſteeme her favours.

sp.speaker: Anno.
sp.l: Sir ſhe ever
For your ſake moſt reſpectively lov'd me.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: The Senate, and the body of this Kingdom,
Are herein (let me ſpeake it without arrogance)
Beholding to her: I will thanke her for it;
And if ſhe have reſerv'd a meanes whereby
I may repay this bounty with ſome ſervice,
She ſhall be then my Patroneſſe: come ſirs,
Wee'l taſte a cup of wine together now.

sp.speaker: Gonz, Fernando,
sp.l: I muſt ſpeake with you in ſecret.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: You ſhall—Now Gaſpero, all's well.

sp.speaker: Gaſ.
sp.l: There's newes
You muſt be acquainted with.
Come, there is no maſter-peece in Art, like Policie. Ex.

div.head: Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: T The Senate is inform'd at full.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: Dreames not of my arivall yet.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Nor thinkes
'Tis poſſible his plots can be diſcover'd:
He fats himſelfe with hopes of Crownes, and Kingdoms,
And laughes ſecurely, to imagine how
He meanes to gull all but himſelfe: when truly,
None is ſo groſely gull'd as he.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: There was never
A more arch villain.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Peace, the Senate comes.
sp.stage: Enter Porphino Poſ. Senators, and Gaſpero, Attend.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: How cloſely, Treaſon cloakes it ſelfe in formes
Of Civill honeſty?

sp.speaker: Poſ.
sp.l: And yet how palpably
Does heaven reveale it?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Gratious Lords.

sp.speaker: Gaſ.
sp.l: The Embaſſadour,
Lord Paulo Michael, Advocate
To the great Duke of Venice.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: You are moſt welcome,
Your Maſter is a juſt and noble Prince.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.l: My Lords, he bad me ſay; that you may know
How much he ſcornes, and (as good Princes ought)
Deſies baſe indirect, and godleſſe treacheries;
To your more Sacred wiſdomes he refers
The puniſhment due to the falſe Gonzalo,
Or elſe to ſend him home to Venice.

sp.speaker: Poſ.
sp.l: Herein
The Duke is royall: Gaſpero the Prince
Of Cyprus anſwer'd he would come.

sp.speaker: Gaſ.
sp.l: My Lords,
He will not long be abſent Enter Philander, and Melitus.

sp.speaker: Porp.
sp.l: You Fernando,
Have made the State your debter: worthy Prince,
We ſhall be ſutors to you for your preſence,
In hearing, and determining of matters
Greatly concerning Candy.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Fathers, I am
A ſtranger.

sp.speaker: Poſ.
sp.l: Why, the cauſe (my Lord) concernes
A ſtranger: pleaſe you ſeat your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: How e're
Unfit, ſince you will have it ſo (my Lords)
You ſhall command me.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: You my Lord Fernando,
With the Ambaſſador, withdraw a while.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: My Lords, we ſhall. Ex.

sp.speaker: Poſ.
sp.l: Melitus, and the Secretary,
Give notice to Gonzalo, that the Senate
Requires his preſence. Ex. Gaſ. and Mel.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: What concernes the buſineſſe? Enter Caſ. and Arca.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Thus noble Prince—

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Let me alone, thou troubleſt me,
I will be heard.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: You know not what you doe.

sp.speaker: Poſ.
sp.l: Forbeare: who's he that is ſo rude? whats he that dares
To interrupt our counſels?

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: One that has guarded,
Thoſe Purple roabes from Cankers worſe then Moaths,
One that hath kept your fleeces on your backs,
That would have been ſnatch'd from you: but I ſee
'Tis better now to be a dog, a Spanniell
In times of Peace, then boaſt the bruſed ſcars,
Purchas'd with loſſe of bloud in noble wars:
My Lords, I ſpeake to you.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Lord Caſſilane,
We know not what you meane.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Yes, you are ſet
Upon a bench of juſtice; and a day
Will come (heare this, and quake ye potent great ones)
When you your ſelves ſhall ſtand before a judge,
Who in a paire of ſcales will weigh your actions,
Without abatement of one graine: as then
You would be found full weight, I charge ye fathers
Let me have juſtice now.

sp.speaker: Poſ.
sp.l: Lord Caſſilane,
What ſtrange diſtemperature provokes diſtruſt
Of our impartiality? be ſure
Wee'l flatter no mans injuries.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: 'Tis well;
You have a Law (Lords) that without remorſe
Dooms ſuch as are belcapred with the curſe
Of foule ingratitude unto death.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: We have.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Then do me juſtice.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Mad-man, whether run'ſt thou?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Peace Decius, I am deafe.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Will you forget
Your greatneſſe and your modeſty?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Hyparcha leave, I will not heare,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Lady; great, gentle, Lady.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Prethee young-man forbeare to interrupt me,
Triumph not in thy fortunes; I will ſpeake.

sp.speaker: Poſ.
sp.l: More uproares yet; who are they that diſturb us?

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: The viper's come; his feares have drawn him hether,
And now (My Lords) be Chronicled for ever,
And give me juſtice againſt this vile Monſter,
This baſtard of my bloud.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: 'Tis juſtice fathers,
I ſue for too: and though I might command it,
(If you remember Lords, whoſe child I was)
Yet I will humbly beg it; this old wretch
'Has forfeited his life to me.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Tricks, tricks;
Complots, devices, 'twixt theſe paire of young-ones,
To blunt the edge of your well temper'd Swords,
Wherewith you ſtrike offendors, (Lords) but I
Am not a baby to be fear'd with bug-beares,
'Tis juſtice I require.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: And I.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You ſpeak too tenderly; and too much, like your ſelf
To meane a cruelty; which would make monſtrous
Your Sexe: yet for the loves ſake, which you once
Pleas'd to pretend, give my griev'd father leave
To vrge his owne revenge; you have no cauſe
For yours: keep peace about ye.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Will you heare me?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Here's ſome ſtrange novelty.

sp.speaker: Poſ.
sp.l: Sure we are mock'd,
Speake one at once: ſay wherein hath your Son
Transgreſs'd the Law?

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: O the groſſe miſts of dulneſſe;
Are you this Kingdomes Oracles, yet can be
So ignorant? firſt heare, and then conſider,
That I begot him, gave him birth and life,
And education, were I muſt confeſſe,
But duties of a father: I did more;
I taught him how to manage Armes, to dare
An Enemy; to court both death and dangers;
Yet theſe were but additions to compleate
A well accompliſh'd Souldier: I did more yet.
I made him chiefe Commander in the field
Next to my ſelfe, and gave him the full proſpect
Of honour, and preferment; train'd him up
In all perfections of a martialliſt:
But he unmindfull of his gratitude,
You know with what contempt of my deſerts,
Firſt kick'd againſt mine honour, ſcorn'd all
My ſervices; then got the palme of glory
Unto himſelfe: yet not content with this,
He (laſtly) hath conſpir'd my death, and ſought
Means to engage me to this Lady's debt,
Whoſe bounty, all my whole eſtate could never
Give ſatisfaction too: now honoured fathers,
For this cauſe only, if your Law be law,
And you the Miniſters of juſtice; then
Thinke of this ſtrange ingratitude in him.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Can this be ſo Antinous?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis all true,
Nor hath my much wrong'd father limn'd my faults
In colours halfe ſo black, as in themſelves,
My guilt hath dyed them: were there mercy left,
Yet mine owne ſhame would be my Executioner:
Lords, I am guilty.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Thou belieſt Antinous,
Thine innocence: alas (my lords) hee's deſperate,
And talkes he knowes not what: you muſt not credit
His lunacy; I can my ſelfe diſprove
This accuſation: Caſſilane, be yet
More mercifull; I beg it.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Time, nor fate,
The world, or what is in it, ſhall not alter
My reſolution; he ſhall dye.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: The Senats
Prayers; or weeping Lovers, ſhall not alter
My reſolution: thou ſhalt dye.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why Madam,
Are ye all Marble?

sp.speaker: Poſ.
sp.l: Leave your ſhifts Antinous,
What plead you to your fathers accuſation?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Moſt fully guilty.

sp.speaker: Poſ.
sp.l: You have doom'd your ſelfe,
We cannot quit you now.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: A burthen'd conſcience
Will never need a hang-man: hadſt thou dar'd
To have denide it, then this Sword of mine
Should on thy head have prov'd thy tongue a lyar.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Thy ſword? wretched old man, thou haſt liv'd too long
To carry peace or comfort to thy grave;
Thou art a man condemn'd: my Lords this tyrant
Had periſh'd but for me, I ſtill ſuppli'd
His miſerable wants; I ſent his daughter
Mony to buy him food; the bread he eate,
Was from my purſe: when he (vaingloriouſly)
To dive into the peoples hearts, had pawn'd
His birth-right, I redeemed it, ſent it to him,
And for requitall, only made my ſuite,
That he would pleaſe to new receive his ſon
Into his favour, for whoſe love I told him
I had been ſtill ſo friendly: But then he
As void of gratitude, as all good nature,
Diſtracted like a mad man, poaſted hether
To pull this vengeance on himſelfe, and us;
For why, (my Lords) ſince by the Law, all meanes
Is blotted out of your commiſſion,
As this hard hearted father hath accus'd
Noble Antinous, his unblemiſhed Son,
So I accuſe this father, and crave judgement.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: All this is but deceit, meere trifles forg'd
By combination to defeat the proceſſe
Of Juſtice, I will have Antinous life.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Sir, what do ye meane?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I will have Caſſilane's.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Cunning and cruell Lady, runs the ſtreame
Of your affections this way? have you not
Conqueſt enough by treading on my grave?
Unleſſe you ſend me thether in a ſhrowd
Steept in my fathers bloud? as you are woman,
As the proteſts of love you vow'd were honeſt;
Be gentler to my father.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Thou haſt a heart of flint: let my intreates,
My teares, the Sacrifice of griefes unfained,
Melt it: yet be a father to thy ſon,
Unmaske thy long beſotted judgement, ſee
A low obedience kneeling at the feet
Of nature: I beſeech you.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Piſh you coſen
Your hopes: your plots are idle: I am reſolute.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Antinous, urge no further.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Hence thou Sorcery
Of a beguiling ſoftneſſe, I will ſtand,
Like the earths Center, unmoved; Lords your breath
Muſt finiſh theſe diviſions: I confeſſe
Civility doth teach I ſhould not ſpeake
Againſt a Lady of her birth, ſo high
As great Erota, but her injuries
And thankeleſſe wrongs to me, urge me to cry
Alowd for juſtice, Fathers.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Whether run you?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: For (honoured fathers) that you all may know
That I alone am not unmatchable
In crimes of this condition, leſt perhaps
You might conceive, as yet the caſe appeares,
That this foule ſtaine, and guilt runs in a bloud;
Before this preſence, I accuſe this Lady
Of as much vile ingratitude to me.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Impudent Traitor!

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Her? O ſpare Antinous;
The world reputes thee valiant, do not ſoyle
All thy paſt nobleneſſe with ſuch a cowardize,
As murthering innocent Ladies will ſtamp on thee?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Brave Prince, with what unwillingneſſe I force
Her follies, and in thoſe her ſin, be witneſſe,
All theſe about me: ſhe is bloudy minded.
And turnes the juſtice of the Law to rigor:
It is her cruelties, not I accuſe her:
Shall I have Audience?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Let him ſpeake my Lords.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Your memory will rot.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Caſt all your eyes
On this, what ſhall I call her? truthleſſe woman,
When often in my diſcontents, the ſway
Of her unruly bloud, her untam'd paſſion,
(Or name it as you liſt) had houre by houre
Sollicited my love, ſhe vow'd at laſt
She could not, would not live unleſſe I granted
What ſhe long ſued for: I in tender pitty,
To ſave a Lady of her birth, from ruine
Gave her her life, and promis'd to be hers:
Nor urg'd I ought from her, but ſecreſie,
And then enjoyn'd her to ſupply ſuch wants
As I perceiv'd my fathers late engagements
Had made him ſubject to; what, ſhall I heape up
Long repetitions? ſhe to quit my pitty,
Not only hath diſcover'd to my father
What ſhe had promis'd to conceale, but alſo
Hath drawne my life into this fatall forfeit;
For which, ſince I muſt dye, crave a like
Equality of juſtice againſt her;
Not that I covet bloud, but that ſhe may not
Practice this art of falſehood on ſome other,
Perhaps more worthy of her love hereafter.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: If this be true—

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: My Lords, be as the Law is,
Indifferent, upright, I do plead guilty:
Now ſir, what glory have you got by this?
'Las man, I meant not to outlive thy doome;
Shall we be friends in death?

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Heare me, the villaine
Scandals her, honour'd Lords.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Leave off to doate,
And dye a wiſe man▪

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I am over-reach'd,
And maſter'd in my own reſolution.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Will ye be wilfull Madam? here's the curſe
Of loves diſdaine.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Why ſit you like dumb Statues?
Demur no longer.

sp.speaker: Poſ.
sp.l: Antinous, death ye aske; and 'tis your doomes,
You in your follies liv'd, dye in your follies.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: I am reveng'd, and thanke you for it.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Yes, and I: Antinous hath been gratious.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sir, may I preſume to crave a bleſſing from you
Before we part.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Yes, ſuch a one as Parents
Beſtow on curſed ſons now, now, I laugh
To ſee how thoſe poore younglings are both cheated
Of life and comfort: looke ye, lookeye, Lords,
I go but ſome ten minutes (more or leſſe)
Before my time, but they have fiuely coz'nd
Themſelves of many, many hopefull yeares
Amidſt their prime of youth and glory; now Enter Annoph.
My vengeance is made ful. Welcome my joy,
Thou comſt to take a ſeaſonable bleſsing
From thy halfe buried fathers hand; I am dead
Already girle, and ſo is ſhe and he,
We all are wormes-meat now.

sp.speaker: Anno.
sp.l: I have heard all;
Nor ſhall you dye alone: Lords on my knees
I beg for juſtice too.

sp.speaker: Porp.
sp.l: 'Gainſt whom, for what?

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: Firſt let me be reſolv'd; does the Law favour
None, be they ne're ſo mighty?

sp.speaker: Porp.
sp.l: Not the greateſt.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: Then juſtly I accuſe of foule ingratitude
(My Lords) you of the Senate all, not one
Excepted.

sp.speaker: Poſ.
sp.l: Porp. Us?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Annophill—

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: You are the Authors
Of this unthrifty bloud-ſhed; when your enemies
Came marching to your gates, your children ſuck'd not
Safe at their mothers breaſts, your very Cloyſters
Were not ſecure, your ſtarting-holes of refuge
Not free from danger, nor your lives your owne:
In this moſt deſperate Extaſie, my father,
This aged man, not onely undertook
To guard your lives, but did ſo; and beat off
The daring foe; for you he pawn'd his lands,
To pay your ſouldiers, who without their pay
Refus'd to ſtrike a blow: but (Lords) when peace
Was purchas'd for you, and victorie brought home;
Where was your gratitude, who in your Coffers
Hoarded the ruſtie treaſure which was due
To my unminded father? he was glad
To live retir'd in want, in penurie,
Whilſt you made feaſts of ſurfeit, and forgot
Your debts to him: The ſum of all is this,
You have been unthankfull to him; and I crave
The rigor of the Law againſt you all.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: My Royall ſpirited daughter!

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: Thou art a worthy wench; let me embrace thee.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: Lords, why doe ye keep your ſeats? they are no places
For ſuch as are offenders.

sp.speaker: Poſ.
sp.l: Though our ignorance
Of Caſsilanes engagements might aſſwage
Severity of juſtice, yet to ſhew
How no excuſe ſhould ſmooth a breach of Law,
I yeeld me to the triall of it.

sp.speaker: Porp.
sp.l: So muſt I:
Great Prince of Cyprus, you are left
The onely Moderator in this difference;
And as you are a Prince be a Protector
To wofull Candy.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What a Scene of miſerie
Hath thine obdurate frowardneſſe (old man)
Drawne on thy Countries boſome? and for that
Thy proud ambition could not mount ſo high
As to be ſtil'd thy Countries onely Patron,
Thy malice hath deſcended to the depth
Of hell, to be renowned in the Title
Of the deſtroyer? doſt thou yet perceive
What curſes all poſterity will brand
Thy grave with? that at once haſt rob'd this kingdome
Of honour and of ſafety.

sp.speaker: Erot.
sp.l: Children yet unborne
Will ſtop their eares when thou art nam'd.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: The world will be too little to containe
The memorie of this deteſted deed;
The Furies will abhorre it.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: What the ſword
Could not enforce, your peeviſh thirſt of honour
(A brave, cold, weak, imaginarie fame)
Hath brought on Candy: Candy groans, not theſe
That are to die.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: 'Tis happineſſe enough
For them, that they ſhall not ſurvive to ſee
The wounds wherewith thou ſtab'ſt the land that gave
Thee life and name.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: 'Tis Candy's wrack ſhall feele—

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: The miſchief of your folly.

sp.speaker: Porp.
sp.l: Poſ. Annophill—

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: I will not be entreated.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Prethee Annophill.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: Why would ye urge me to a mercy which
You in your ſelfe allow not?

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: 'Tis the Law,
That if the party who complaines, remit
The offender, he is freed: is't not ſo Lords?

sp.speaker: Porp.
sp.l: Poſ. 'Tis ſo.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Antinous, By my ſhame obſerve
What a cloſe witch-craft popular applauſe is:
I am awak'd, and with cleare eyes behold
The Lethargie wherein my reaſon long
Hath been be-charm'd: Live, live, my matchleſſe ſonne,
Bleſt in thy fathers bleſsing; much more bleſt
In thine owne vertues: let me dew thy cheeks
With my unmanly teares: Riſe, I forgive thee:
And good Antinous, if I ſhall be thy father
Forgive me: I can ſpeak no more.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Deare Sir,
You new beget me now—Madam your pardon,
I hartily remit you.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: I as freely
Diſcharge thee Caſsilane.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: My gracious Lords,
Repute me not a blemiſh to my Sex,
In that I ſtrove to cure a deſperate evill
With a more violent remedy: your lives,
Your honours are your owne.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Then with conſent
Be reconcil'd on all ſides: Pleaſe you fathers
To take your places.

sp.speaker: Poſ.
sp.l: Let us againe aſcend,
With joy and thankfulneſſe to heaven: And now
To other buſineſſe Lords.

div.stage: Enter Gaſpero, and Melitus, with Gonzalo.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Two howres and more Sir,
The Senate hath been ſet.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: And I not know it?
Who ſits with them?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: My Lord, the Prince of Cyprus.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: VVhy how comes that to paſſe?

sp.speaker: Gaſ.
sp.l: Some waighty cauſe
I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Now Lords the buſineſſe? ha?
VVho's here, Erota?

sp.speaker: Porp.
sp.l: Secretarie doe your charge
Upon that Traitor.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Traytor?

sp.speaker: Gaſ.
sp.l: Yes, Gonzalo, Traitor,
Of treaſon to the peace and ſtate of Candy,
I doe arreſt thee.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Me? thou dog?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: With Licenſe
From this grave Senate, I arreſt thee likewiſe
Of Treaſon to the State of Venice.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Ha?
Is Michael here? nay then I ſee
I am undone.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: I ſhall not be your Queen,
Your Dutcheſſe, or your Empreſſe.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Dull, dull braine.
O I am fool'd?

sp.speaker: Gaſ.
sp.l: Look Sir, do you know this hand?

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.l: Do you know this Seale? Firſt (Lords) he writes to Venice,
To make a perfect league, during which time
He would in private keep ſome Troops in pay,
Bribe all the Centinells throughout this kindom,
Corrupt the Captaines; at a Banquet poyſon
The Prince, and greateſt Peeres, and in concluſion
Yield Candy ſlave to Venice.

sp.speaker: Gaſ.
sp.l: Next, he contracted
With the Illuſtrious Princeſſe, the Lady Erota,
In hope of marriage with her, to deliver
All the Venetian gallantry, and ſtrength,
Upon their firſt arrivall, to the mercy
Of her and Candy.

sp.speaker: Erot.
sp.l: This is true Gonzalo.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Let it be true: what then?

sp.speaker: Poſ.
sp.l: My Lord Ambaſſadour,
What's your demand?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: As likes the State of Candy,
Either to ſentence him as he deſerves
Here, or to ſend him like a ſlave to Venice.

sp.speaker: Porph.
sp.l: We ſhall adviſe upon it.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: O the devills,
That had not thruſt this trick into my pate—
A Politician foole? deſtruction, plague
Candy and Venice both.

sp.speaker: Poſ.
sp.l: Porp. Away with him.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Come ſir, Ile ſee you ſafe. Exeunt. Gonz. Mel.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: Lords, e're you part
Be witneſſe to another change of wonder;
Antinous, now be bold, before this preſence,
Freely to ſpeak, whether or no I us'd
The humbleſt meanes affection could contrive,
To gaine thy love.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Madam, I muſt confeſſe it,
And ever am your ſervant.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: Yes Antinous,
My ſervant, for my Lord thou ſhalt be never:
I here diſclaim the intereſt thou hadſt once
In my too paſsionate thoughts. Moſt noble Prince,
If yet a relique of thy wonted flames
Live warme within thy boſome, then I bluſh not
To offer up the aſſurance of my faith,
To thee that haſt deſerv'd it beſt.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: O Madam,
You play with my calamity.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: Let heaven
Record my truth for ever.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: With more joy
Then I have words to utter, I accept it.
I alſo pawne you mine.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: The man that in requitall
Of noble and un-ſought affection
Growes cruell, never lov'd, nor did Antinous.
Yet herein (Prince) ye are beholding to him;
For his neglect of me humbled a pride,
Which to a vertuous wife had been a Monſter.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: For which Ile ranke him my deſerving friend.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Much comfort dwell with you, as I could wiſh
To him I honour moſt.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: O my Antinous,
My owne, my owne good ſon.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: One ſuit I have to make.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: To whom Fernando?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Lord Caſſilane to you.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: To me?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: This Lady
Hath promiſed to be mine.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: Your bleſsing ſir;
Brother your love.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You cannot ſir beſtow her
On a more noble gentleman.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: Saiſt thou ſo?
Antinous I confirm it. Here Fernando,
Live both as one; ſhe is thine.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: And herein ſiſter,
I honour you for your wiſe ſetled love.
This is a day of Triumph, all Contentions
Are happily accorded: Candy's peace
Secur'd, and Venice vow'd a worthy friend. Exeunt.
